case_vignette: Three days after undergoing an open cholecystectomy, an obese 57-year-old woman has fever, chills, and a headache. She has right-sided chest pain that increases on inspiration and has had a productive cough for the last 12 hours. She had an episode of hypotension after the operation that resolved with intravenous fluid therapy. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy 16 years ago for multiple fibroids of the uterus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 17 years. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mm Hg. Inspiratory crackles are heard at the right lung base. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a healing surgical incision below the right ribcage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Infectious Diseases. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. It's important for the diagnosis to know the characteristics of the sputum. Can you please describe the color and consistency of it?
Actually, I'm not able to describe the color or consistency; I just mentioned that I have a productive cough.
Have you been in contact with anyone who was sick recently?
No, I didn't mention being in contact with anyone who was sick.
Do you have any shortness of breath or difficulty breathing?
I didn't say I have shortness of breath, but my chest pain does get worse when I take a breath in.

No, I didn't mention experiencing any recent weight loss or night sweats.

I had an abdominal hysterectomy 16 years ago for multiple fibroids in my uterus, and I've smoked for 17 years.

I didn't mention having nausea or vomiting.
Final Diagnosis: Postoperative pneumonia or possibly pulmonary embolism.
